ARTICLE XI. - STANDARDS FOR STORMWATER MANAGEMENT Sec. 105-303. - Intent; purpose. (a) Intent. It is the intent of this article to provide standards and criteria to protect, maintain, and enhance the public health, safety, environment, and general welfare by establishing minimum requirements and procedures to control the adverse effects of increased post-development stormwater runoff and nonpoint source pollution associated with new development and redevelopment. It has been determined that proper management of postdevelopment stormwater runoff will minimize damage to public and private property and infrastructure, 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 220/426 safeguard the public health, safety, environment, and general welfare of the public, and protect water and aquatic resources. (b) Purpose. (1) Require that new development and redevelopment maintain the pre-development hydrologic response in their post-development state as nearly as practicable in order to reduce flooding, stream bank erosion, nonpoint source pollution, increases in stream temperature, and maintain the integrity of stream channels and aquatic habitats. (2) Establish minimum post-development stormwater management standards and design criteria for the regulation and control of stormwater runoff quantity and quality. (Ord. of 8-8-2005(2), Â§ 1101; Ord. of 6-4-2007, Â§ 1(1101)) Sec. 105-304. - Applicability, exemptions, and compliance. (a) Applicability. (1) An adequate drainage system, including necessary ditches, pipes, culverts, drains, inlets, bridges, etc., shall be provided for the proper drainage of all surface water. (2) All persons proposing the residential or commercial subdivision of property as defined in the county zoning ordinance set forth in chapter 119 shall prepare a stormwater management plan. No final subdivision plat shall be approved and no development or building permit shall be issued until and unless the stormwater management plan, consisting of a hydrology study report and engineering plans and specifications, has been reviewed and approved by the director of planning or his appointed reviewing entity, and has been installed, except as exempt in subsection (b) of this section. (3) This article is applicable to new development and/or redevelopment that disturbs one acre or more. (b) Exemptions from storm drainage requirements. The following development activities are exempt from the provisions of this section and the requirement of providing a stormwater management plan: (1) Agricultural land management. (2) Additions or modifications to existing single-family detached dwellings. 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 221/426 (c) Compliance. (1) Georgia Department of Transportation (GDOT) Standard Specifications and Details shall be used for construction of all stormwater management structures and appurtenances. (2) Erosion control practices shall comply with county development regulations and the Georgia Manual for Sediment and Erosion Control. (Ord. of 8-8-2005(2), Â§ 1102; Ord. of 6-4-2007, Â§ 1(1102)) Sec. 105-305. - Hydrologic and hydraulic study required. (a) Permanent stormwater detention facilities providing for the storage and controlled release of stormwater runoff shall be required for any residential or commercial development activity that will increase the peak rate of discharge from pre-development conditions, except: (1) The subdivision of property for residential purposes where no new roadway construction is proposed and all the lots exceed three acres in size. (2) The subdivision of property for residential purposes where all lots exceed five acres. (3) The re-development of existing commercial sites where the post-development peak stormwater discharge from the site can be shown to be less than 110 percent of the pre-development discharge for the two-, five-, ten-, and 25-year storm return frequencies. (b) Calculations shall he provided to demonstrate existing and proposed conditions for stormwater conveyance, stormwater detention and routing, and site discharge. A hydrology and hydraulic study shall be required for all stormwater detention facilities. (c) Hydrology studies shall be prepared and sealed by a design professional registered to practice in the state and must include the following: (1) A narrative of site description. (2) 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 222/426 A summary showing existing and developed conditions and allowable release rate, including any bypass or offsite sub-basins, for the two-, five-, ten-, 25-, 50-, and 100-year storm events. (3) An explanation of the methodology used for hydraulic and hydrologic calculations. (4) The following exhibits: a. Drainage area maps for existing and proposed conditions. b. Sub-basin delineation and identification. c. Drainage area, hydrologic data/parameters. d. Detail of outlet control structure. e. All hydrology and hydraulic studies shall meet the standards and employ the methods listed here: 1. The reservoir routing method or an equivalent method shall be used in sizing detention ponds (the bowstring method is not acceptable.) 2. Output from this routing is required for each design storm. 3. Runoff from areas that bypass detention, when combined with discharge from detention basins, must be shown to be less than or equal to pre-developed flow rates in the receiving waterway. 4. The minimum time of concentration used for hydrologic calculations shall be five minutes. 5. Appropriate intensity-duration-frequency curves for the study area shall be used in rainfall calculations. 6. The maximum drainage area for use of the rational method is five acres. Drainage areas exceeding five acres should be analyzed by the soil conservation service method or other appropriate technique. 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 223/426 (Ord. of 8-8-2005(2), Â§ 1103; Ord. of 6-4-2007, Â§ 1(1103)) Sec. 105-306. - Standards to be used in designing detention facilities. Permanent detention facilities will be required, except where exempt as listed in section 105-305(a), and shall be designed so that the following standards shall apply: (1) All stormwater detention facilities shall be designed to accommodate the two-, five-, ten-, 25-, 50-, and 100-year storm events. (2) Detention facilities shall be subject to the provisions of Georgia Safe Dam Program, and the Georgia EPD Rules for Dam Safety (Ga. Comp. Rules and Regs. ch. 391-3-8). (3) Detention facilities shall provide a minimum of one foot of freeboard between the maximum water surface elevation and the top of the detention berm. (4) Ponds shall be designed to discharge to defined drainage ditches or natural drainage pathways. (5) All closed drainage systems (i.e., culverts, pipes, etc.) must have a headwall, or safety end section when appropriate, on their inflow and outflow ends meeting state department of transportation standards, along with the required riprap or other erosion and sediment control device found in the Manual for Erosion and Sediment control in Georgia. As part of the hydrology study, consideration should be given to the flow capacity of downstream drainage structures. (6) The steepest fill slopes shall be 3:1, and cut slopes shall be no steeper than 2:1. Slopes proposed to be steeper shall be reviewed and conditionally approved on a case-by-case basis by the director of planning or other engineering reviewer approved by the county. (7) A ten-foot-wide access road shall be required along the top of the berm and around the circumference of the pond where topography does not prohibit its construction. (8) A fence of high quality, durable material, including wood, iron, or other metal, shall be required for all detention facilities having a maximum water storage depth of more than four feet. The fence must also comply with the following standards: a. The fence shall be at least six feet high. b. 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 224/426 Fence posts shall be set in concrete ten feet on centers. c. There shall be a minimum ten-foot-wide locked gate for access. d. The fence shall not be installed across the slope of a dam or dike, but installed completely around the pond and containing the dike and access road. (Ord. of 6-4-2007, Â§ 1(1104)) Sec. 105-307. - Grading and drainage plans. Grading and drainage plans shall be a part of all stormwater management plans and shall include the following items and meet the following standards: (1) The location, size and length of all existing drainage structures shall be shown on a topographic layout with twofoot contour intervals. Existing and proposed contours shall be shown. (2) The 25-year storm event shall be used in designing the stormwater collection and conveyance system. (3) Calculations showing how the sizing of each drainage structure was determined (drainage area, runoff coefficient, flow path for inlet time, etc.). (4) Storm sewer catchbasins, drop inlets, manholes, and junction boxes shall be designed by the developer's engineer to state department of transportation standards. (5) Catchbasins shall be located outside of intersection radii unless unusual circumstances cause undue hardship, in which case the director of planning may waive this requirement. (6) Inlet spacing shall be designed for a maximum gutter spread of eight feet for the 25-year storm. (7) Off-street inlets will be installed to prevent excessive flow over curbs or between house lots where such conditions exist. (8) Bridges shall be designed for a 100-year storm event. (9) 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 225/426 Energy dissipation devices, such as splash pads, riprap, and stilling basins, shall be provided at the outlet of every culvert and piped discharge system. The size and type of energy dissipation device to be used shall be designed in accordance with sound engineering practices. If riprap is used, the length, shape, and size of riprap shall be designed in accordance with the Manual for Erosion and Sediment Control in Georgia and shall be detailed on the plan for all outlet locations. (Ord. of 6-4-2007, Â§ 1(1105)) Sec. 105-308. - Cross drain pipes. (a) Cross drains under streets shall not be less than 18 inches in size. (b) Minimum clearances: (1) 18 inches between the bottom of the street base and the exterior crown of the culvert. In all cases at least 24 inches of cover shall be provided. (2) A minimum of six inches between underground utilities and exterior crown of culverts. (3) The inlet and outlet end of all storm drain pipes including driveway pipe shall have either flared-end sections or concrete headwalls that meet the standards of GDOT Standard 1120 or 1125. (4) All storm piping or surface swales shall extend to the detention facility. (5) Maximum continuous length of pipe shall be 300 feet for pipes less than 42 inches. (6) Junction boxes having access to the pipe shall be constructed to meet the requirements of GDOT Standard 1030D, current edition. (Ord. of 6-4-2007, Â§ 1(1106)) Sec. 105-309. - Storm drain profiles. All stormwater management plans shall include storm drain profiles that show: (1) Existing and proposed grade. (2) 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 226/426 Vertical factor of five to ten with respect to horizontal scale. (3) Structure identification corresponding to grading and drainage plan. (4) Hydraulic grade line (HGL). (5) Pipe material. (6) Pipe length. (7) Invert elevations for all pipes. (8) Construction drawings shall include a pipe chart showing the following information: a. Upstream structure ID. b. Inlet drainage area. c. Inlet runoff coefficient. d. Sub-basin time of concentration. e. System time of concentration. f. Rainfall intensity. g. Incremental flow at each basin. h. Cumulative flow conveyed in the system to that point. 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 227/426 i. Pipe diameter, material, length and slope. j. Maximum velocity of ten feet per second at the 25-year design flow. k. Minimum velocity of two feet per second at the two-year design flow. l. Upstream and downstream invert elevations. (9) Elevation of throat of inlet. (10) Provide a minimum of 0.1 foot drop between inverts across the structure. (11) When pipe sizes increase, match crowns of pipes. (Ord. of 6-4-2007, Â§ 1(1107)) Sec. 105-310. - Open channels. Construction drawings shall include a typical section of surface conveyance channels, provided for each reach if the cross section changes. Open channels shall be protected from erosion by seeding or lining with riprap as defined in the Manual for Erosion and Sediment Control in Georgia. (Ord. of 6-4-2007, Â§ 1(1108)) Sec. 105-311. - Materials and installation. (a) GDOT Standard 1030D, current edition, shall be used in determining class (concrete) or gauge of pipe under fill, method of backfilling and pipe installation. (b) Only reinforced concrete pipe shall be used within street rights-of-way for arterial roads and major collectors. Concrete pipe shall not be used on grades exceeding ten percent. Metal pipe may be used within the rights-ofway of local streets and for driveway culverts. Metal pipe shall either be corrugated steel (AASHTO M-36) with aluminized Type II or bituminous coating, or corrugated aluminum alloy pipe (AASHTO M-196). (c) Corrugated high-density polyethylene (HPPE) pipe, smooth lined Type 5, may only be used for residential driveway applications and must be manufactured and installed in strict compliance with GDOT Standard 1030-P. HDPE applications shall not exceed 36 inches in diameter. 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 228/426 (d) Pipe installation shall conform to GDOT Standard Specifications for Construction of Transportation Systems, current edition. Before any traffic over a storm drain is allowed, the developer shall provide an adequate depth and width of compacted backfill to protect the structure from damage or displacement. The developer shall remove any debris or silt that constricts the flow through a pipe as often as necessary to maintain drainage. All pipe structures shall be cleaned before the work is accepted. Any damage or displacement that may occur due to traffic or erosion shall be repaired or corrected at the developer's expense. (Ord. of 6-4-2007, Â§ 1(1109)) Sec. 105-312. - Driveway culverts. (a) Driveway culverts may be aluminum, steel, or corrugated plastic pipe approved by the county road department. (b) The inlet and outlet end of all driveway culverts shall have either flared-end sections or concrete headwalls that meet the standards of GDOT Standard 1120 or 1125. (Ord. of 6-4-2007, Â§ 1(1110)) Sec. 105-313. - Field changes. (a) Minor changes in construction plans caused by field conditions shall be made at the direction and with the approval of the road superintendent and the director of planning with the cost of such changes to be paid by the developer. (b) A complete set of as-builts shall be kept on site at all times and made available to county personnel as requested. At the conclusion of the project, a clean set of as-builts, reflecting constructed conditions, shall be submitted to the county in both hard copy and electronic form. (Ord. of 6-4-2007, Â§ 1(1111)) Secs. 105-314â105-344. - Reserved. ARTICLE XII. - EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION CONTROL Sec. 105-345. - Applicability. (a) See chapter 113 for regulations pertaining to soil erosion and sedimentation control. (b) Except for construction of single-family residences, where compliance with section 105-346 is required, the director of planning shall enforce compliance with the minimum requirements as if a permit had been issued. (Ord. of 8-8-2005(2), Â§ 1201) 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 229/426 Sec. 105-346. - Minimum requirements for erosion and sedimentation control using best management practices. (a) See chapter 113 for regulations pertaining to soil erosion and sedimentation control. (b) The construction of single-family residences otherwise exempted from the requirements of this article shall be subject to issuance of a residential land disturbance permit. Such permit shall be used to ensure compliance with the minimum requirements set forth herein. (Ord. of 8-8-2005(2), Â§ 1202) Secs. 105-347â105-365. - Reserved. ARTICLE XIII. - EARTHWORK SPECIFICATIONS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY Sec. 105-366. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Satisfactory soil material means clean subsoil, free from debris, roots, topsoil, frozen material, and shall contain no rock larger than three inches in diameter. Unsuitable soil material means soil material not capable of being compacted to the density required, rock material larger than three inches in diameter, debris, and organic material or soil with high organic content. (Ord. of 8-8-2005(2), Â§ 1301) Sec. 105-367. - Job conditions. The applicant shall be required to: (1) Verification. Verify existing grades and layouts grade stakes for building and appurtenances. If existing grades are at variance with drawings, notify the engineer and receive instructions prior to proceeding. (2) Protection. a. Protect benchmarks and monuments; if disturbed or destroyed, notify the surveyor to replace in original position. b. Protect existing facilities and adjacent property. Prevent ponding or washing of water on site and on adjacent property. Erect silt fences as indicated on drawings and where existing site conditions require. c. Protect areas outside limits of construction from encroachment by construction personnel or equipment. 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 230/426 d. Protect active utilities and remove or relocate active utilities encountered but not shown on plans. e. Identify and protect utilities for duration of project. (Ord. of 8-8-2005(2), Â§ 1302) Secs. 105-368â105-392. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PRODUCTS Sec. 105-393. - Materials. The applicant shall use the following fill materials: (1) Structural fill. Satisfactory soil materials for use under structures, slabs and pavement are defined as those complying with ASTM D 2487 classifications GM, GC, SW, SP, SM, SC, ML, and CL. Unsuitable soils for these purposes are those classified as Pt, OH, OL, CH and MH. Soils classified as CH may be suitable for constructing cutoff trenches and cores of berms at stormwater detention basins. (2) General fill materials. a. Fill materials shall be conhesionless or display low plasticity, shall be free of organic or other perishable material and shall not contain stones larger than three inches in diameter or rubble. No material shall be placed when frozen. b. If additional material, other than that to be obtained from excavation, is required for backfilling and grading, the contractor shall use appropriate material. (Ord. of 8-8-2005(2), Â§ 1311) Secs. 105-394â105-414. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - EXECUTION Sec. 105-415. - Excavation. The applicant shall adhere to the following requirements for excavations: (1) If unsuitable soil material, including rock or muck is encountered, clearing away earth to expose suitable material. (2) 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 231/426 Protect excavations against cave-ins, and freezing. Provide bracing, shoring, and sheeting to contain excavations. Slope embankments over five feet zero inches in height at 45-degree angle away from excavation or shore. Shoring design shall be by a registered engineer engaged by and paid by the contractor. When freezing can be anticipated prior to placing of concrete, protect excavations or delay carrying excavations to full depth until concrete can be placed. (3) Maintain excavations free of surface water. Provide pumps if required to drain excavations. Provide and maintain temporary drainage ditches as required. (4) Notify the engineer immediately of subsurface water encountered and await instructions. (5) Trench excavation. Excavate trenches to a maximum width equal to pipe diameter plus two feet zero inches for pipe two feet six inches and smaller; or pipe diameter plus two feet six inches for pipe exceeding two feet six inches diameter. (Ord. of 8-8-2005(2), Â§ 1321) Sec. 105-416. - Fill and backfill. The applicant shall adhere to the following requirements when performing fill and backfill operations: (1) Provide satisfactory soil material to perform earthwork operations indicated, including filling and backfilling to bring grade to elevations indicated. (2) Preparation of surfaces to receive fill: a. Remove vegetation, debris, unsuitable soil materials, obstructions, and deleterious materials from ground surface prior to placement of fills. Break up sloped surfaces steeper than one vertical to four horizontal so that material will bond with existing surface. b. All areas shall be proof-rolled prior to receiving fill. Proof rolling shall be accomplished with overlapping passes in each of two perpendicular directions with a full loaded tandem axle dump truck so similarly loaded rubber tires vehicle. All areas judged to rut excessively or pumping shall be over-excavated and backfilled with suitable fill and compacted as specified in this section. (3) Placement and compaction. Place fill material in lifts not exceeding eight inches loose thickness. Before compaction, moisten or aerate each layer to provide the optimum moisture content. Compact each lift to specified percentage of maximum density for area classification. Place no backfill or fill material on surfaces that are muddy, frozen, or contain frost or ice. 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 232/426 (4) Backfill against pipe in lifts not exceeding four inches loose thickness. Place backfill along pipe haunches by hand and compact using hand tamper to specified density. Place backfill evenly along both sides of pipe for full length. Compact each lift to specified percentage of maximum density. (Ord. of 8-8-2005(2), Â§ 1322) Sec. 105-417. - Compaction. The applicant shall adhere to the following requirements when performing compaction operations: (1) Perform compaction of soil materials for fills using proper mechanical soil compaction equipment for type and size materials to be compacted. (2) Percentage of maximum density requirements. All soil density testing shall be conducted in accordance with ASTM D-698, Standard Proctor Compaction Test. Compaction shall conform to the following requirements: Structural fill. Place soil in lifts of eight inches loose measure and compact to 95 percent of the standard proctor maximum dry density. (3) Soil material that has been removed because it is too wet to permit compaction may be stockpiled or spread where directed by the engineer and permitted to dry. Assist drying by dicing, harrowing, or pulverizing until moisture content is reduced to satisfactory value, as determined by moisture-density relation tests. (Ord. of 8-8-2005(2), Â§ 1323) Sec. 105-418. - Grading. The applicant shall adhere to the following requirements when performing grading operations: (1) Grade areas to lines and elevations indicated, including adjacent transition areas. Smooth finished surface within specified tolerances, compact and bring to uniform levels or slopes between points where elevations are shown, or between such points and existing grades. (2) Finished surfaces shall be free from irregular surface changes, and as follows: a. Surfaces under walks and pavements. Shape surface of areas under walks to line, grade, and cross section, with finish surface not more than 0.1 foot above or below required subgrade elevation. b. Grassed areas. Shape areas to receive topsoil to within 0.3 foot above or below required subgrade elevation. (3) 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 233/426 Compaction. After grading, compact subgrade surfaces to depth and percentage of maximum density for each area classification. (4) Grade areas adjacent to buildings to drain away from building and to prevent ponding. Finish grades shall be within 0.3 foot of indicated elevations. (5) Where compacted areas are disturbed by construction operations, scarify surfaces, reshape and re-compact to required density. (6) Redistribute stockpiled topsoil to uniform depth over graded areas. (7) Remove excess topsoil and other soil matter and debris on site at approved location. (8) At completion of finish grading operation, the site shall be ready for landscaping. (9) Protection of graded areas. Protect newly graded surfaces from traffic and erosion. Keep free of debris. Where graded or compacted surfaces are damaged by subsequent operation, return to indicated grade and state of compaction. (Ord. of 8-8-2005(2), Â§ 1324) Secs. 105-419â105-449. - Reserved. ARTICLE XIV. - ASPHALT PAVING SPECIFICATION; LOCAL ROADS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY Sec. 105-450. - Submittals. The applicant shall submit the following documentation: (1) Certificates. Provide certificates stating that materials supplied comply with specifications. Certificates shall be signed by the asphalt producer and the contractor. (2) Mix design. Submit mix design for each course to the engineer for acceptance. (Ord. of 8-8-2005(2), Â§ 1401) Sec. 105-451. - Job conditions. The applicant shall adhere to the following requirements when performing asphalt paving under the following job conditions: 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 234/426 (1) Weather limitations. a. Do not conduct paving operations when surface is wet or contains excess of moisture which would prevent uniform distribution and required penetration. b. Construct asphalt courses only when atmospheric temperature is above 55 degrees Fahrenheit for one-inch lift or 45 degrees Fahrenheit for 1Â½-inch lift, when the underlying base is dry and when weather is not rainy. c. Place base coat when the temperature is above 35 degrees Fahrenheit and rising. (2) Grade control. Establish and maintain the required lines and grades for each course during construction operations. (3) Traffic control. a. Maintain vehicular and pedestrian traffic during paving operations, as required for other construction activities. b. Provide flagmen, barricades, warning signs, and warning lights, as applicable, for movement of traffic and safety and to cause the least interruption of work. (4) Standards. For materials and methods of construction, conform to the state department of transportation's Standard Specifications for Construction of Roads and Bridges, 2001 edition, including modifications, amendments, and supplements. (5) All cutting and paving shall match existing pavement and shall form a smooth, even transition. (Ord. of 8-8-2005(2), Â§ 1402) Sec. 105-452. - Testing. (a) Asphalt paving testing will be performed by an independent testing agency paid by the county. A testing fee will be charged to the developer prior to issuance of the grading permit to cover testing costs. The independent testing agency shall report directly to the road building inspector. The amount of the testing fee shall be as established by the board of commissioners from time to time. 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 235/426 (b) Testing shall include in-place courses for compliance with specified density, thickness, and surface smoothness requirements. (c) Testing agency shall take one four-inch diameter core per 1,000 square yards of paved surface at locations selected by the engineer for density and thickness test. The contractor shall repair holes resulting from coring to matching existing paving prior to placing surface course. (d) Density. The testing shall compare density of in-place material against a laboratory specimen of the same mixture subjected to 50 blows of a Standard Marshall hammer on each side of the specimen. Minimum acceptable density of in-place material shall be 97 percent of recorded laboratory specimen density. (e) Allowable variation in thickness shall be as follows: Base course Â± Â½ inch Binder course Â± Â¼ inch Surface course Â± Â¼ inch (f) Surface smoothness. Test finished surface of each asphalt course for smoothness using a ten-foot straight edge. Intervals of tests shall be as directed by engineer. Surfaces will not be acceptable if exceeding the following: Base course Â± Â½ inch in ten feet Binder course Â± Â¼ inch in ten feet Surface course Â± Â¼ inch in ten feet (g) Contractor's duties relative to testing include: (1) Notifying laboratory of conditions required testing. (2) Coordinating with laboratory for field testing. (3) Paying costs for all testing including that performed beyond scope of that required and for retesting where initial tests reveal nonconformance with specified requirements. 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 236/426 (Ord. of 8-8-2005(2), Â§ 1403) Secs. 105-453â105-472. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PRODUCTS Sec. 105-473. - Paving materials. The applicant shall use the following paving materials: (1) Aggregate base course or soil cement base. a. Crushed stone base. The base course shall consist of at least six inches of graded aggregate base material compacted to 100 percent maximum dry density. b. Soil cement base. The minimum base course shall consist of at least six inches of suitable soil (high mica content is not suitable) stabilized with ten percent of Portland cement by volume (approximately 42.3 pounds per square yard). (2) Surface course: Meeting GDOT Specification, section 400, for Type "E" or "F" hot-mix asphalt (12 mm and 9 mm Superpave), as indicated on the drawings. (3) Bituminous prime coat: Meeting GDOT Specification, section 413. (4) Bituminous tack coat: Meeting GDOT Specification, section 413. (Ord. of 8-8-2005(2), Â§ 1411) Secs. 105-474â105-499. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - EXECUTION Sec. 105-500. - Subgrade preparation. The applicant shall undertake the following subgrade preparations: (1) Prior to beginning of pave work, inspect subgrade for loose or soft material, rock or excess moisture. (2) Proof roll cut subgrade using loaded, 20-ton dump truck or similar weight construction equipment to verify that subgrades are stable and to identify loose or soft areas requiring undercutting or stabilization. Proof rolling shall be under surveillance of the testing agency. 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 237/426 (3) Stabilization or soft or unstable subgrades shall be accomplished to minimum depth of 12 inches. Stabilizing aggregate shall be of type specified for base course material. (4) After the earthwork has been completed, all storm drainage, water, and sanitary sewer utilities have been installed within the right-of-way as appropriate, and backfill in all such ditches thoroughly compacted to the satisfaction of the county engineer or road building inspector, the subgrade shall be brought to the lines, grades and typical roadways section shown on the construction plans. (5) Utility trenches cut in the subgrade shall be backfilled and compacted properly. Compaction tests at the rate of one per 150 feet of trench shall be provided to verify compaction. (6) If requested by the road building inspector, a surveyor must certify the subgrade to within six inches of the design grade prior to base placement. (Ord. of 8-8-2005(2), Â§ 1421) Sec. 105-501. - Placing asphalt paving. The applicant shall adhere to the following requirements when placing asphalt paving: (1) Aggregate course. Place, grade, and compact to minimum thickness as indicated on the drawing and in accordance with ASTM D1557-78 and GDOT Specification, section 815. (2) Bituminous prime coat. Apply primer coat after base course has been compacted and brought to grade. Select material and proper application temperature as specified in GDOT Specification, section 412. (3) Bituminous tack coat. Apply tack coat immediately prior to surface course application. Tack coat material and application procedure shall comply with GDOT Specification, section 413. (4) Surface course. Apply surface course to minimum compacted thickness as indicated on the drawing and in accordance with GDOT Specification, section 400. (5) Placing asphalt concrete paving. Place asphalt at proper temperature and compact to at least 95 percent of laboratory density in accordance with ASTM D1559-76. While hot, compact mixture by rolling. Asphalt temperature at time of application shall be in accordance with GDOT Specification, sections 400 and 424. (Ord. of 8-8-2005(2), Â§ 1422) 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 238/426 Sec. 105-502. - Cleaning and protection. The applicant shall adhere to the following requirements at the completion of the operations: (1) At completion of each operation, remove excess or spilled materials from site. Sump or spread on excess asphalt material on project site. (2) After placement of surface course, no vehicular traffic shall be allowed on pavement until it has cooled and hardened and in no case sooner than 12 hours. (Ord. of 8-8-2005(2), Â§ 1423) Secs. 105-503â105-527. - Reserved. ARTICLE XV. - APPROVED CONSTRUCTION DETAILS Sec. 105-528. - Figures. (Ord. of 8-8-2005(2), art. 15) Secs. 105-529â105-547. - Reserved. ARTICLE XVI. - LEGAL STATUS PROVISIONS Sec. 105-548. - Conflict with other ordinances. Portions of other ordinances that conflict with portions of this chapter are repealed. Non-conflicting parts of those ordinances remain in effect. The zoning provisions of chapter 119 shall take precedence over this chapter where zoning issues conflict. (Ord. of 8-8-2005(2), Â§ 1601)

div.head: Chapter 107 - FLOODS
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): (38) State Law referenceâ Georgia Safe Dams Act of 1978, O.C.G.A. Â§ 12-5-370 et seq.; construction and operation of watershed and flood control projects by counties, O.C.G.A. Â§ 22-3-100 et seq. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Sec. 107-1. - Findings of fact. 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 239/426 (a) The flood hazard areas of the county are subject to periodic inundation which results in loss of life and property, health and safety hazards, disruption of commerce and governmental services, extraordinary public expenditures for flood relief and protection, and impairment of the tax base, all of which adversely affect the public health, safety and general welfare. (b) These flood losses are caused by the occupancy in flood hazard areas of uses vulnerable to floods, which are inadequately elevated, floodproofed, or otherwise unprotected from flood damages, and by the cumulative effect of obstructions in floodplains causing increases in flood heights and velocities. (Code 2000, Â§ 34-31; Ord. of 5-5-1997, art. 1, Â§ B; Ord. of 7-6-2010, art. 1, Â§ B) Sec. 107-2. - Statement of purpose. It is the purpose of this chapter to promote the public health, safety and general welfare and to minimize public and private losses due to flood conditions in specific areas by provisions designed to: (1) Require that uses vulnerable to floods, including facilities which serve such uses, be protected against flood damage at the time of initial construction; (2) Restrict or prohibit uses which are dangerous to health, safety and property due to water or erosion hazards, or which increase flood heights, velocities, or erosion; (3) Control filling, grading, dredging and other development which may increase flood damage or erosion; (4) Prevent or regulate the construction of flood barriers which will unnaturally divert floodwaters or which may increase flood hazards to other lands; and (5) Control the alteration of natural floodplains, stream channels, and natural protective barriers, which are involved in the accommodation of floodwaters. (Code 2000, Â§ 34-32; Ord. of 5-5-1997, art. 1, Â§ C; Ord. of 7-6-2010, art. 1, Â§ C) Sec. 107-3. - Objectives. The objectives of this chapter are: (1) To protect human life and health; (2) 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 240/426 To minimize damage to public facilities and utilities such as water and gas mains, electric, telephone and sewer lines, streets and bridges located in floodplains; (3) To help maintain a stable tax base by providing for the sound use and development of floodprone areas in such a manner as to minimize flood blight areas; (4) To minimize expenditure of public money for costly flood control projects; (5) To minimize the need for rescue and relief efforts associated with flooding and generally undertaken at the expense of the general public; (6) To minimize prolonged business interruptions; and (7) To ensure that potential homebuyers are notified that property is in a flood area. In all areas of special flood hazard, the following provisions are required: (1) New construction and substantial improvements of existing structures shall be anchored to prevent flotation, collapse or lateral movement of the structure. (2) New construction and substantial improvements of existing structures shall be constructed with materials and utility equipment resistant to flood damage. (3) New construction or substantial improvements of existing structures shall be constructed by methods and practices that minimize flood damage. (4) Elevated buildings. All new construction or substantial improvements of existing structures that include any fully enclosed area located below the lowest floor formed by foundation and other exterior walls shall be designed so as to be an unfinished or flood resistant enclosure. The enclosure shall be designed to equalize hydrostatic flood forces on exterior walls by allowing for the automatic entry and exit of floodwaters. a. Designs for complying with this requirement must either be certified by a professional engineer or architect or meet the following minimum criteria: 1. 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 252/426 Provide a minimum of two openings having a total net area of not less than one square inch for every square foot of enclosed area subject to flooding; 2. The bottom of all openings shall be no higher than one foot above grade; and 3. Openings may be equipped with screens, louvers, valves or other coverings or devices provided they permit the automatic flow of floodwaters in both directions. b. So as not to violate the "lowest floor" criteria of this chapter, the unfinished or flood-resistant enclosure shall only be used for parking of vehicles, limited storage of maintenance equipment used in connection with the premises, or entry to the elevated area; and c. The interior portion of such enclosed area shall not be partitioned or finished into separate rooms. (5) All heating and air conditioning equipment and components (including ductwork), all electrical, ventilation, plumbing, and other service facilities shall be designed and/or located so as to prevent water from entering or accumulating within the components during conditions of flooding. (6) Manufactured homes shall be anchored to prevent flotation, collapse, or lateral movement. Methods of anchoring may include, but are not limited to, use of over-the-top or frame ties to ground anchors. This standard shall be in addition to and consistent with applicable state requirements for resisting wind forces. (7) New and replacement water supply systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the system. (8) New and replacement sanitary sewage systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the systems and discharges from the systems into floodwaters. (9) On-site waste disposal systems shall be located and constructed to avoid impairment to them or contamination from them during flooding. (10) Any alteration, repair, reconstruction or improvement to a structure, which is not compliant with the provisions of this chapter, shall be undertaken only if the nonconformity is not furthered, extended or replaced. All recreational vehicles placed on sites must either: 1. Be on the site for fewer than 180 consecutive days; 2. Be fully licensed and ready for highway use (a recreational vehicle is ready for highway use if it is licensed, on its wheels or jacking system, attached to the site only by quick-disconnect type utilities and security devices, and has no permanently attached structures or additions); or 3. The recreational vehicle must meet all the requirements for new construction, including the anchoring and elevation requirements of subsection (3)a. and c. of this section. (4) Floodway. Located within areas of special flood hazard established in section 107-6 are areas designated as floodways. A floodway may be an extremely hazardous area due to velocity floodwaters, debris or erosion potential. In addition, the area must remain free of encroachment in order to allow for the discharge of the base flood without increased flood heights. Therefore, the following provisions shall apply: a. Encroachments are prohibited, including earthen fill, new construction, substantial improvements or other development within the regulatory floodway. Development may be permitted, however, provided it is demonstrated through hydrologic and hydraulic analyses performed in accordance with standard engineering practice that the encroachment shall not result in any increase in flood levels or floodway widths during a base flood discharge. A registered professional engineer must provide supporting technical data and certification thereof. 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 255/426 b. Only if subsection (4)a of this section is satisfied, then any new construction or substantial improvement shall comply with all other applicable flood hazard reduction provisions of this article. (Code 2000, Â§ 34-92; Ord. of 5-5-1997, art. 4, Â§ B; Ord. of 7-6-2010, art. 4, Â§ B) Sec. 107-72. - Building standards for streams without established base flood elevations and/or floodways (A zones). Located within the areas of special flood hazard established in section 107-6, where streams exist but no base flood data have been provided (A zones), or where base flood data have been provided but a floodway has not been delineated, the following provisions apply: (1) When base flood elevation data or floodway data have not been provided in accordance with section 107-6, then the county zoning administrator shall obtain, review, and reasonably utilize any scientific or historic base flood elevation and floodway data available from a federal, state, or other source, in order to administer the provisions of this article. Only if data are not available from these sources, then the provisions of subsections (2) and (3) of this section shall apply: (2) No encroachments, including structures or fill material, shall be located within an area equal to the width of the stream or 20 feet, whichever is greater, measured from the top of the stream bank, unless certification by a registered professional engineer is provided demonstrating that such encroachment shall not result in more than a one-foot increase in flood levels during the occurrence of the base flood discharge. (3) In special flood hazard areas without base flood elevation data, new construction and substantial improvements of existing structures shall have the lowest floor of the lowest enclosed area (including basement) elevated no less than three feet above the highest adjacent grade at the building site. (Note: Require the lowest floor to be elevated one foot above the estimated base flood elevation in A zone areas where a limited detail study has been completed). Openings sufficient to facilitate the unimpeded movements of floodwaters shall be provided in accordance with standards of section 107-70(4). a. All heating and air conditioning equipment and components (including ductwork), all electrical, ventilation, plumbing, and other service facilities shall be elevated no less than three feet above the highest adjacent grade at the building site. b. The county zoning administrator shall certify the lowest floor elevation level and the record shall become a permanent part of the permit file. (Code 2000, Â§ 34-93; Ord. of 5-5-1997, art. 4, Â§ C; Ord. of 7-6-2010, art. 4, Â§ C) Sec. 107-73. - Standards for areas of special flood hazard (zones AE) with established base flood elevations without designated floodways. Located within the areas of special flood hazard established in section 107-6, where streams with base flood elevations are provided but no floodways have been designated (AE zones), the following provisions apply: 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 256/426 (1) No encroachments, including fill material, new structures or substantial improvements shall be located within areas of special flood hazard, unless certification by a registered professional engineer is provided demonstrating that the cumulative effect of the proposed development, when combined with all other existing and anticipated development, will not increase the water surface elevation of the base flood more than one foot at any point within the community. The engineering certification should be supported by technical data that conforms to standard hydraulic engineering principles. (2) New construction or substantial improvements of buildings shall be elevated or floodproofed to elevations established in accordance with section 107-71 (Ord. of 7-6-2010, art. 4, Â§ D) Sec. 107-74. - Standards for areas of shallow flooding (AO zones). Areas of special flood hazard established in section 107-6 may include designated AO shallow flooding areas. These areas have base flood depths of one to three feet above ground, with no clearly defined channel. The following provisions apply: (1) Elevation. a. All new construction and substantial improvements of residential and nonresidential structures shall have the lowest floor, including basement, elevated to the flood depth number specified on the flood insurance rate map (FIRM), above the highest adjacent grade. If no flood depth number is specified, the lowest floor, including basement, shall be elevated at least three feet above the highest adjacent grade. Openings sufficient to facilitate the unimpeded movements of floodwaters shall be provided in accordance with standards of section 107-70(4). b. The county zoning administrator shall certify the lowest floor elevation level and the record shall become a permanent part of the permit file. (2) New construction or the substantial improvement of a nonresidential structure may be floodproofed in lieu of elevation. The structure, together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities, must be designed to be watertight to the specified FIRM flood level plus one foot, above highest adjacent grade, with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water, and structural components having the capability of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads and the effect of buoyancy. A registered professional engineer or architect shall certify that the design and methods of construction are in accordance with accepted standards of practice for meeting the provisions above, and shall provide such certification to the official as set forth above and as required in section 107-46(b)(1)c and (b)(2). (3) Drainage paths shall be provided to guide floodwater around and away from any proposed structure. (Code 2000, Â§ 34-94; Ord. of 5-5-1997, art. 4, Â§ D; Ord. of 7-6-2010, art. 4, Â§ E) 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 257/426 Sec. 107-75. - Standards for subdivisions. (a) All subdivision and/or development proposals shall be consistent with the need to minimize flood damage. (b) All subdivision and/or development proposals shall have public utilities and facilities such as sewer, gas, electrical and water systems located and constructed to minimize flood damage. (c) All subdivision and/or development proposals shall have adequate drainage provided to reduce exposure to flood hazards. (d) For subdivisions and/or developments greater than 50 lots or five acres, whichever is less, base flood elevation data shall be provided for subdivision and all other proposed development, including manufactured home parks and subdivisions. Any changes or revisions to the flood data adopted herein and shown on the FIRM shall be submitted to FEMA for review as a conditional letter of map revision (CLOMR) or conditional letter of map amendment (CLOMA), whichever is applicable. Upon completion of the project, the developer is responsible for submitting the as-built data to FEMA in order to obtain the final LOMR. (Code 2000, Â§ 34-95; Ord. of 5-5-1997, art. 4, Â§ E; Ord. of 7-6-2010, art. 4, Â§ F) Sec. 107-76. - Standards for critical facilities. (a) Critical facilities shall not be located in the 100-year floodplain or the 500-year floodplain. (b) All ingress and egress from any critical facility must be protected to the 500-year flood elevation. (Ord. of 7-6-2010, art. 4, Â§ G)

div.head: Chapter 109 - PLANNING
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): (39) State Law referenceâ Regional development centers, O.C.G.A. Â§ 50-8-30 et seq. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Secs. 109-1â109-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - COMPREHENSIVE PLAN (RESERVED) FOOTNOTE(S): (40) State Law referenceâ Coordinated and comprehensive planning by counties and municipalities, O.C.G.A. Â§ 36-70-1 et seq. 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 258/426 Secs. 109-19â109-39. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - ZONING POWER STANDARDS Sec. 109-40. - Zoning ordinance amendments. The planning and zoning commission and the board of county commissioners will, when considering a proposed amendment to the zoning ordinance, first determine whether the limitation imposed by such an amendment, if any, on the right to unrestricted use of property which might result from the proposed amendment is necessary to promote the public health, safety, morality or general welfare. In considering whether to recommend a change in the zoning classification of any particular property, the planning and zoning commission will balance the benefit to the public of the present zoning classification of the property against the detriment to the property owner, and scrutinize the application in light of the character of the land in question and the effect of the zoning decision upon the property owner's rights. In making these determinations, the following standards must be considered: (1) The existing land uses and zoning classification of nearby property. (2) The suitability of the property for the proposed rezoning. (3) The length of time the property has been vacant. (4) The threat to the public health, safety, morality, and welfare if rezoned. (5) The extent to which the value of the subject property is diminished by the present zoning, as compared to its potential value under the proposed zoning. (6) The balance between the hardship on the property owner and the benefit to the public in not rezoning. (7) Whether the subject property has a reasonable economic use as currently zoned. (8) Whether the proposed zoning will be a use that is suitable in view of the uses and development of nearby property or will adversely affect the existing use or usability of nearby property. (9) Whether there are other existing or changing conditions affecting the use and development of the property which give supporting grounds for either approval or disapproval of the zoning proposal. (10) Whether the zoning proposal is in conformity with the policies and intent of the land use plan. 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 259/426 (11) Whether the zoning proposal would overburden the public utilities, schools, and streets presently existing to serve the site. (12) Whether the zoning proposal would have a substantial adverse impact on the environment, including, but not limited to, drainage, soil erosion and sedimentation, flooding, air quality, and water quality and quantity. (Code 2000, Â§ 46-71; Res. of 3-3-1994) Secs. 109-41â109-68. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - PUBLIC HEARINGS Sec. 109-69. - Required. The planning and zoning commission must conduct a public hearing on zoning amendments. The responsibility of conducting the public hearing is delegated to the planning and zoning commission by the board of county commissioners under provisions specified in the Zoning Procedures Law (O.C.G.A. Â§Â§ 36-66-1 to 36-66-5). Notice of the hearing stating the time, place, and purpose, including notice of the date the board of county commissioners is expected to make a final decision, must be published in two consecutive issues in a newspaper of general circulation in the county, the first insertion being at least 15 days but not more than 45 days before the hearing. The location of the property, area to be rezoned, present zoning classification, and proposed zoning classification must be indicated in the newspaper notice. In addition, the applicant and all property owners within 250 feet of the subject property will be notified of the date of the hearing by the planning and zoning commission by first class mail at least 15 days but not more than 45 days before the hearing. Any person may appear at the hearing, or have a representative attend instead. (Code 2000, Â§ 46-101) Sec. 109-70. - Policies and procedures. The following policies and procedures will be observed in conducting the required public hearing: (1) The hearing will be held in the county courthouse. (2) Written comments on the subject of the hearing may be submitted by any citizen or property owner at any time prior to the adjournment of the hearing. (3) All persons desiring to be heard orally may present their views at the hearing. The length of time of oral presentations permitted to each speaker will be determined by the planning and zoning commission and governed by the planning and zoning commission chairperson, depending upon the number of persons present and desiring to speak. Remarks of a personal nature will not be tolerated. (4) The applicant is allowed to respond to any issues that are raised. (5) 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 260/426 Any person desiring a transcript of the hearing must arrange for a court reporter at their own expense. (6) All questions and comments from the floor will be addressed to the chairperson of the planning and zoning commission or the commission member then presiding. The planning and zoning commission members may ask pertinent questions of the applicant. (7) Standing to challenge a zoning decision is not conferred by being permitted to speak orally at a hearing, nor by being permitted to file statements or pleadings. (8) The planning and zoning commission shall have discretion to continue a hearing to a later date if the materials submitted or views expressed require more time for study and consideration than may reasonably be allocated in one meeting. (Code 2000, Â§ 46-102) Secs. 109-71â109-98. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION Sec. 109-99. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Planning commission means the Jasper County Planning and Zoning Commission. (Code 2000, Â§ 46-131; Ord. of 5-2-1994(2), Â§ 102) Sec. 109-100. - Established. This article establishes the county planning and zoning commission. The Zoning Procedures Law (O.C.G.A. Â§Â§ 36-66-1 to 36-66-5) authorizes such administrative officers, bodies, and agencies as the board of county commissioners may establish for the efficient exercise of its zoning powers. (Code 2000, Â§ 46-132; Ord. of 5-2-1994(2), Â§ 103) Sec. 109-101. - Scope. This article provides for the following: (1) Establishing the county planning and zoning commission. (2) Setting regulations for membership, appointments, terms of office, and compensation of members. (3) Setting rules and procedures for operation. 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 261/426 (4) Defining the powers of the county planning and zoning commission. (5) Repealing conflicting ordinances. (Code 2000, Â§ 46-133; Ord. of 5-2-1994(2), Â§ 101) Sec. 109-102. - Purpose. The purpose of the planning and zoning commission is as follows: (1) Advise the board of county commissioners on applications for amendment to this article by examining amendment applications and providing written recommendations with reasons for the recommendation to the board of county commissioners as specified in chapter 119, article IX. (2) Dispense general information about this article to the public upon request. (3) Propose amendments to this article. (4) Maintain and update the county land use plan so that it may provide a current database with which decisions on proposed amendments to this article may be made that utilize sound planning principles. (5) Carry out an ongoing comprehensive planning program which, like the land use plan, will provide current data on which decisions regarding this article may be based that utilize sound planning principles. (6) Advise the board of county commissioners on matters of zoning, as appropriate. (Code 2000, Â§ 46-134; Ord. of 5-2-1994(2), Â§ 104) Sec. 109-103. - Membership and appointments. The planning and zoning commission consists of at least three but no more than five members. All members must reside within the county and shall be appointed by the board of county commissioners. None of the members of the planning and zoning commission may hold any elected public office except that one member may also be a member of the county board of appeals. Commission members may be removed by the board of county commissioners for cause, upon written charges, and after a public hearing. Members of the planning and zoning commission will be disqualified to act upon any matter before the planning and zoning commission in which they have a personal financial interest or other conflict of interest. (Code 2000, Â§ 46-135; Ord. of 5-2-1994(2), Â§ 105) Sec. 109-104. - Terms of office. 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 262/426 The term of office for each member of the planning and zoning commission is for three years. However, in the appointment of the first commission, two members will be appointed for three years, two for two years, and one for one year. Any vacancy in the membership will be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as the initial appointment. If one appointee is from the county board of appeals and he ceases to be a member of the board of appeals during the term of his appointment to the planning and zoning commission, his membership in the planning and zoning commission will terminate and the board of county commissioners may name another member of the planning and zoning commission to fill the unexpired term of its original appointee. (Code 2000, Â§ 46-136; Ord. of 5-2-1994(2), Â§ 106) Sec. 109-105. - Compensation. Planning and zoning commission members will receive compensation for their service as determined by the board of county commissioners. (Code 2000, Â§ 46-137; Ord. of 5-2-1994(2), Â§ 107) Sec. 109-106. - Rules and procedures. (a) The planning and zoning commission will elect one of its members as chairperson. The chairperson will serve for one year. At the end of that term, he must either be re-elected or a successor elected. (b) The planning and zoning commission will appoint a secretary, who may be an officer of the county or the planning and zoning commission. (c) A planning and zoning commission quorum shall be three members. (d) Unless otherwise stated in this section, the planning and zoning commission will follow Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised, when holding its meetings. The planning and zoning commission has the authority to change its rules of procedure. (e) Meetings of the planning and zoning commission will be held at the call of the chairperson, or, in his absence, the acting chairperson. (f) The chairperson or the acting chairperson may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses by subpoena. The planning and zoning commission must keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote of each member upon each question, or if absent or failing to vote, indicating such fact. The planning and zoning commission must also keep records of its examinations and other official actions, all of which must be immediately filed in the office of the planning and zoning commission and will be public record. (g) A decision of the planning and zoning commission must be recorded in the minutes for the meeting at which the decision was made, and must contain a statement of the grounds of its decision or action. 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 263/426 (h) No application for the same property will be received or heard by the planning and zoning commission twice within the same six-month period. However, that limitation does not affect the right of the planning and zoning commission to grant a rehearing as provided in the rules and procedures adopted by the planning and zoning commission. (Code 2000, Â§ 46-138; Ord. of 5-2-1994(2), Â§ 108) Sec. 109-107. - Appealing an action of the planning and zoning commission. (a) If the planning and zoning commission executes an action which the developer or other aggrieved party believes to be contrary to law, that action may be appealed. Findings of fact, however, may not be appealed. Recommendations on ordinance amendments are not actions. Such an appeal must be filed within 30 days of the date on which the action by the planning and zoning commission was taken. (b) The board of appeals has jurisdiction for hearing appeals concerning actions of the planning and zoning commission related to this article. Applications for appeal may be submitted to the administrative officer, who will transmit them to the board of appeals for its consideration. (c) When an action of the administrative officer or planning and zoning commission is appealed, all construction or other activity authorized by the appealed action must be stopped immediately. In certain cases, however, the administrative officer may feel that the stopping of such construction or other activity authorized by the appealed action will cause imminent peril to life or property, in which case the administrative officer may certify to the board of appeals that, by reason of facts stated in the certificate, the halting of construction or other activity authorized by the appealed action would in his opinion cause imminent peril to life or property. In such cases, the construction or other activity authorized by the appealed action is allowed to continue unless a restraining order is granted by either the board of appeals or a court of appropriate jurisdiction. (d) When an application for appeal of an action of the planning and zoning commission is received, the board of appeals will set a time and place for a public hearing on the appeal. Notice of the hearing must be published in two consecutive issues in a newspaper of general circulation in the county, the first insertion being at least 15 days before the hearing. In addition, the parties to the appeal will be notified of the date of the hearing by the board of appeals by first class mail at least 15 days before the hearing. Any person may appear at the hearing, or have a representative attend instead. (e) The board of appeals will make a decision concerning the appeal and record the decision in the minutes for that meeting. Further appeal on points of law may be made to the superior court of the county. (Code 2000, Â§ 46-139; Ord. of 5-2-1994(2), Â§ 109)

div.head: Chapter 111 - SIGNS
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 264/426 (41) State Law referenceâ Prohibited placement of campaign posters, signs and advertisements, O.C.G.A. Â§ 16- 7-58; control of signs and signals, O.C.G.A. Â§ 32-6-50 et seq.; unlawful placement of signs within right-of-way of public road, O.C.G.A. Â§ 32-6-51; outdoor advertising near state highways, O.C.G.A. Â§ 32-6-70 et seq. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL Sec. 111-1. - Jurisdiction. This chapter applies to all land within the unincorporated limits of the county. (Code 2000, Â§ 54-1; Ord. of 5-2-1994(1), Â§ 103) Sec. 111-2. - Purpose. (a) The purpose of this chapter is to seek to promote aesthetic conditions and reduce possible traffic hazards within the county along its streets and roads. The promotion of sound sign use patterns is intended to reduce or eliminate the occurrence of certain conditions which can threaten the general health, safety, and welfare of the residents of the county. (b) This chapter shall provide for the following to: (1) Define certain terms used in this chapter. (2) Establish minimum standards for signs. (3) Provide procedures for administering this chapter. (4) Provide penalties for violation of this chapter. (5) Repeal conflicting ordinances. (Code 2000, Â§ 54-2; Ord. of 5-2-1994(1), Â§Â§ 104, 105) Sec. 111-3. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Sign means any surface bearing lettered or pictorial matter designed to convey information visually and exposed to public view; or any structure designed to carry such visual information. Signs are classified into the following types: 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 265/426 (1) Advertising separate use sign means a sign which directs attention to a business, commodity, service, or entertainment offered elsewhere than the premises where the sign is displayed. (2) Identification sign means a sign attached to a building which is used to identify only the name of the organization or enterprise occupying the premises. (3) Point of business sign means a freestanding sign which directs attention to a business, commodity, service, or entertainment offered upon the premises where the sign is displayed. (4) Portable sign means a sign, lighted or not, which is designed to be moved and advertising copy changed periodically. (Code 2000, Â§ 54-3; Ord. of 5-2-1994(1), Â§ 106) Sec. 111-4. - Prohibited signs. The following signs are expressly prohibited in all zoning districts: (1) Signs imitating warning signals are prohibited. No sign shall display lights resembling the flashing lights customarily used in traffic signals or on police, fire, ambulance, or rescue vehicles; nor shall any signs use the words, slogans, dimensional shape or size of any governmental traffic sign. (2) No signs, except traffic signs and signals and informational signs erected or authorized by a public agency, are permitted within any street or highway right-of-way. (3) Signs painted or attached to natural features such as trees or rocks, utility poles, or fenceposts are prohibited. (4) Fluttering ribbons and banners are prohibited. (5) Signs within 300 feet of any officially designated historical site or monument, except signs pertaining to that particular site or monument, are prohibited. (Code 2000, Â§ 54-4; Ord. of 5-2-1994(1), Â§ 109) Sec. 111-5. - General regulations. (a) Signs shall not exceed 35 feet in height. 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 266/426 (b) No sign shall be located in a manner which will obstruct the view of traffic signals or the view at intersections. (c) All lighted signs must be erected and maintained to preclude light spill onto adjacent residential properties by being located not less than 50 feet from the nearest residential property line or residential district and being shielded if necessary. (d) All signs requiring a permit shall be set back from roads with deeded rights-of-way a minimum of 35 feet from the edge of the right-of-way; on county proscriptive roads with no deeded right-of-way, the front setback is 65 feet from the centerline of such road. Signs shall be a minimum of 20 feet from all property lines other than those abutting a road. (e) Advertising separate use signs shall meet the following requirements: (1) They are allowed in agricultural districts by special exception (approval of the planning and zoning commission) and are permitted in commercial and manufacturing districts. (2) The maximum size face for a freestanding sign is 125 square feet. (3) In agricultural districts, there must be a minimum of 1,000 feet between signs, measured along the road right-ofway. (4) In commercial or manufacturing districts only one per lot, or combinations of lots under one ownership at the time of passage of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, unless separated by a minimum of 1,000 feet. (f) Point of business signs (freestanding) shall meet the following requirements: (1) They are allowed in agricultural, commercial and manufacturing districts only. (2) Only one sign per use is allowed, or one per shopping center. If property fronts on two roads, one is allowed on second frontage also. (3) 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 267/426 The maximum area of sign face shall be 125 square feet, except shopping centers, where 300 square feet maximum is allowed. (g) Identification signs, attached to a building, shall meet the following requirements: (1) They are allowed in agricultural, commercial and manufacturing districts only. (2) Only one per occupant is allowed. (3) The maximum area of the sign face shall be 30 percent of the total area of the front face of the building but no larger than 125 square feet. (h) Portable signs shall meet the following requirements: (1) They are allowed in agricultural, commercial and manufacturing districts only. (2) Portable signs shall be used for on-premises advertising only. (3) Portable signs may be lighted but must not flash. (4) In commercial or manufacturing districts, only one per lot, or combinations of lots under one ownership at the time of passage of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, unless separated by a minimum of 1,000 square feet. (5) Maximum area of the sign face shall be 50 square feet. (Code 2000, Â§ 54-5; Ord. of 5-2-1994(1), Â§ 110) Sec. 111-6. - Unlawful signs. The administrative officer may inspect at any time each sign regulated by the provisions of this chapter, whether permitted or not. Should any sign be installed or maintained improperly or should any violation of this chapter be noted, the administrative officer will notify the owner or lessee of such sign in writing of the reasons for noncompliance. The administrative officer is empowered to revoke any permit issued upon failure of a sign owner or lessee to comply with the provisions of this chapter. The owner or lessee shall have three business days from receipt of notice to bring a sign into compliance or it may be removed by the county at the expense of the owner or lessee. 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 268/426 (Code 2000, Â§ 54-6; Ord. of 5-2-1994(1), Â§ 111) Sec. 111-7. - Nonconforming signs. (a) Nonconforming signs must not be replaced by another nonconforming sign except for replacement of lettered or pictorial information. (b) Minor repairs and maintenance are allowed but no structural repairs or changes in size are allowed except to make the sign comply with this chapter. (c) New point of business or identification signs related to legally existing nonconforming uses are allowed provided they comply with sign regulations applicable to the district in which the use is permitted. (Code 2000, Â§ 54-7; Ord. of 5-2-1994(1), Â§ 112) Secs. 111-8â111-32. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PERMITS Sec. 111-33. - Required. All signs shall be erected or maintained in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and only those signs that are permitted by this chapter shall be erected. No sign, except those listed in section 111-34 as not requiring a permit, shall be placed without a permit from the administrative officer. Application for permits to erect, hang, or place a sign shall be submitted, accompanied by plans showing the area of the sign, the method of illumination, if any, the exact location proposed for such sign, the method of support, the vertical distance between such sign and the finished grade, and the horizontal distance between such sign and the street right-ofway line or centerline if no right-of-way. The application shall also include a photograph or line drawing of the face of the sign showing exactly what is to be portrayed. Each applicant shall, upon the request of the administrative officer, submit any additional information deemed necessary by such officer. The board of county commissioners may establish a fee schedule for sign permits. (Code 2000, Â§ 54-41; Ord. of 5-2-1994(1), Â§ 107) Sec. 111-34. - Exceptions. The following signs do not require a permit and are allowed in any zoning district subject to the following provisions: (1) Traffic or other government signs, legal notices, railroad crossing signs, danger, and temporary, emergency or non-advertising signs. (2) Real estate signs not exceeding six square feet in residential areas which advertise the sale, rental or lease of the premises upon which the signs are located; only one sign is permitted for each street on which the building or property faces. (3) 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 269/426 Warning signs and no trespassing signs. (4) Professional nameplates not exceeding one square foot in area. (5) Bulletin boards not over 32 square feet in area for public, civic, charitable or religious institutions when located on the premises of these institutions. (6) Signs denoting the architect, lender, engineer, or contractor when placed on work under construction and not exceeding 32 square feet in area. (7) Occupational signs denoting only the name and profession of an occupant in a commercial building and not exceeding two square feet in area. (8) Signs not exceeding 12 square feet in area giving information concerning the location or use of off-street parking facilities or loading and unloading facilities. (9) Signs indicating bus stops, taxistands, and similar transportation facilities. (10) Political signs not to exceed 12 square feet in area, but not to be located on utility poles, trees or natural objects. Signs are to be located on public or private property only with permission of the property owner. Political signs shall be removed by the candidate, property owner of occupier of the property where such sign is located within three days after such candidate has been finally elected or defeated. (11) Garage or yard sale signs not to exceed four square feet in area when mounted on a substantial frame and erected on private property with the owner's approval. (12) Memorial signs, historical signs or tablets, names of buildings and date of erection when cut into any masonry surface or when constructed of bronze or other noncombustible material. (13) Residential development (or subdivision) name signs not exceeding 50 square feet. (Code 2000, Â§ 54-42; Ord. of 5-2-1994(1), Â§ 108)

div.head: Chapter 113 - SOIL EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION CONTROL
div.p: FOOTNOTE(S): 5/30/2019 Jasper County, GA Code of Ordinances 270/426 (42) State Law referenceâ Georgia Surface Mining Act of 1968, O.C.G.A. Â§ 12-4-70 et seq.; Georgia Water Quality Control Act, O.C.G.A. Â§ 12-5-20 et seq.; Erosion and Sedimentation Act of 1975, O.C.G.A. Â§ 12-7-1 et seq.; stop work orders, O.C.G.A.
